title: Using break and default in switch

questions.question: What does the break statement do in a switch?

options.value: Restarts the switch from the beginning

questions.explanation: The break statement causes the program to exit the entire switch block immediately and continue execution after the closing brace.

questions.question: What happens when you forget to include break in a switch case?

options.value: Fall-through occurs and subsequent cases execute

questions.explanation: Without break, fall-through occurs - the program continues executing code in subsequent cases until it encounters a break or reaches the end of the switch.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the default case in a switch statement?

options.value: It executes first before all other cases
It handles values that don't match any explicit case
It makes the switch run faster

questions.explanation: The default case acts as a catch-all that executes when none of the other cases match the switch expression, similar to an else clause.

questions.question: Where is the default case typically placed in a switch statement?
questions.explanation: The default case is typically placed at the end of the switch statement, though Java allows it anywhere within the switch block.

questions.question: Is a break statement required after the default case when it's at the end?

options.value: No, it's optional since there are no more cases to fall through to
Only if there are more than 5 cases
Only if the default contains multiple statements

questions.explanation: When the default case is positioned last, the break statement is optional because there are no remaining cases to fall through to.
Since case 2 has no break, fall-through occurs. The program prints "Two", then continues to case 3 and prints "Three" before hitting the break.

questions.question: What is intentional fall-through useful for?

options.value: Grouping multiple cases that execute the same code

questions.explanation: Intentional fall-through allows multiple cases to execute the same code block, useful when several different values should trigger identical behavior.
Since grade is 'F' and no case matches, the default case executes, printing "Try harder".

questions.question: Is the default case required in a switch statement?

options.value: No, but it's highly recommended for handling unexpected inputs
Yes, the code won't compile without it

questions.explanation: The default case isn't strictly required, but it's highly recommended as it provides a safety net for unexpected inputs and makes code more robust.
Since day is 5, it matches case 5. All cases 1-5 fall through to print "Weekday", demonstrating intentional fall-through for grouping cases.

questions.question: What is the most common mistake when writing switch statements?

options.value: Placing default at the wrong position

questions.explanation: Forgetting break statements is the most common mistake, leading to unintended fall-through behavior that can be difficult to debug.
The expression num / 5 evaluates to 10 / 5 which equals 2. This matches case 2, so "B" is printed.

questions.question: When using intentional fall-through, what should you do?

options.value: Add a comment indicating it's intentional

questions.explanation: When using intentional fall-through, it's good practice to add a comment indicating the fall-through is deliberate, so other programmers know it wasn't a mistake.
Since letter is 'b' and doesn't match any of the vowel cases (a, e, i), the default case executes and prints "Consonant".

questions.question: What does fall-through mean in a switch statement?

options.value: The switch statement fails to execute
Execution continues into subsequent cases without break

questions.explanation: Fall-through occurs when execution continues into subsequent cases because there's no break statement to exit the switch block.
Since month is 15 and doesn't match case 1 or 2, the default case executes and prints "Invalid", demonstrating how default handles invalid input.
